items.author: James Berardinelli
items.content: Passionate and magical, Forrest Gump is a tonic for the weary of spirit.

items.author: Todd McCarthy
items.content: Manages the difficult feat of being an intimate, even delicate tale played with an appealingly light touch against an epic backdrop.

items.author: Jonathan Rosenbaum
items.content: The results are skillful, highly affecting, and ultimately more than a little pernicious.

items.author: Austin Chronicle
items.content: A remarkable balance of sentimentality and harshness, darkness and light.

items.author: Mike Clark
items.content: Doesn't sound like a very prepossessing title, but prepare to be taken aback by "what's in a name." [6 July 1994, Life, p.1D]
The film's technical brilliance and sentimental kick seduced many viewers unsuspecting of its polemical intent.

items.author: Kenneth Turan
items.content: It's most successful when it is being off-center, a state of grace it doesn't quite have the nerve to maintain. [6 July 1994, Calendar, p. F-1]

items.author: Elvis Mitchell
items.content: Has the elements of an emotionally gripping story. Yet is feels less like a romance than like a coffee-table book celebrating the magic of special effect. [6 July 1994, p. C9]

Clearly a great event, Forrest Gump is not, however, a great film. It has the form of an epic without real depth or resonance; the trappings of satire without a coherent attitude; and the semblance of historical revisionism without a critical sensibility.

items.author: Owen Gleiberman
items.content: It is also glib, shallow, and monotonous, a movie that spends so much time sanctifying its hero that, despite his "innocence," he ends up seeming about as vulnerable as Superman.
